docs.lead_paragraph: Japan has agreed in principle to simplify some of the rules governing access to its pharmaceuticals and medical equipment markets, American trade negotiators said today. But the negotiators said Japan's agreements were too vague to judge whether the changes would result in gains for American products here. A spokesman for Japan's Foreign Ministry praised the measures, saying, ''All in all, I think this was a fairly positive move on our part.''

headline.main: JAPAN TO EASE DRUG PRODUCT RULES

docs.snippet: Japan has agreed in principle to simplify some of the rules governing access to its pharmaceuticals and medical equipment markets, American trade negotiators said today.   But the negotiators said Japan's agreements were too vague to judge whether...

byline.original: By SUSAN CHIRA, Special to the New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: A NEW study charges that a high number of psychiatric patients at a New York hospital have been seriously misdiagnosed. And the study is refueling a controversy over whether the problem is one that exists generally at a significant number of other mental institutions and clinics in the United States, especially those that are understaffed or underfinanced. Some psychiatrists believe severe harm has been done as a result of the misdiagnoses. Mistaking various forms of depression for schizophrenia is the most frequent error, according to the report, and the harm is said to be caused essentially by the use of powerful but inappropriate drugs. Officials of the New York hospital and other leading members of the psychiatric community vigorously deny the extent and seriousness of the problem.

headline.main: STATE HOSPITAL ACCUSED OF WRONG DIAGNOSES, FUELING DEBATE OVER NATION'S MENTAL CARE
